item.title: Report E-2025050045
item.description:
Report E-2025050045

Identified by scraper @ 2025-06-02T15:18:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-04-30
  • City: STRAFFORD
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 10 square foot area of concrete dock floor and estimated that seventy-five (75) gallons of material was released due to a puncture from a skid damaging one (1) 270-gallon IBC poly tote. Clean Harbors personnel used gravity feed to complete a tote transfer from the damaged IBC poly tote to one (1) 250-gallon IBC poly tote. Contractor personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area. The absorbents, cut up tote, rags, and PPE were all containerized. One (1) 55-gallon metal drum contains approximately 45 gallons of product and granular absorbents. One (1) superstack contains cut up poly tote, spent oil dri, rags, and PPE. One (1) 250-gallon IBC poly tote contains transferred material. Before demobilization, the generated waste was staged onsite, and Dayton Freight approved of the cleanup. The generated waste will remain onsite for the Dayton Freight Lines team to coordinate disposal

  • City: EARTH CITY
  • State: MO

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AT APPROXIMATELY 18:45 THE SUPERVISOR FROM THE IRREG SORTING AREA APPROACHED THE DMP CAGE AND INFORMED A RESPONDER THEY HAD A LEAKING BUCKET ON AN IRREG CART. AFTER DONNING PROPER PPE AND RETRIEVING A FULLY STOCKD SPILL CART, THE RESPONDER THEN HEADED TO THE SCENE OF THE SPILL. UPON ARRIVAL THE RESPONDER NOTICED A PLASTIC CLOSED HEAD 5 GALLON BUCKET LAYING ON ITS SIDE WITH A PUDDLE OF LIQUID ON THE FLOOR NEXT TO IT. AFTER REFERRING TO THE DECISION TREE AND APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET THE RESPONDER ACTED ACCORDINGLY. THE BUCKET WAS THEN TRANSPORTED BACK TO THE DMP CAGE FOR FURTHER PROCESSING. AFTER CLOSER INSPECTION IT WAS DETERMINED THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS A PUNCTURE HOLE TO THE BODY OF THE CONTAINER. AFTER FOLLOWING THE DMP DISPOSAL FLOW CHART THE LIQUID AND CONTAINER WERE ALL PROPERLY DISPOSED OF.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: A shipment was moved from Veolia's Mooresville 10-day facility to Veolia's Creedmoor facility using a Freehold Cartage Inc trailer. Upon unloading the following morning, a material handler noticed a pallet of triple-stacked and shrink-wrapped carboys had shifted. Two of the carboys were off the pallet and leaning against another drum. One of the carboy drum containers had a loose cap, resulting in less than a pint of material spilling onto the trailer floor. The spill was cleaned up, the cap was tightened, and all other caps were checked before the pallet was shrink-wrapped once more for continued transportation to the final destination facility.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 2041 EST, XSJ notified ERTS of a cargo release inside trailer #3178473. It was reported an unknown material was leaking from a 250-gallon IBC tote. The spill is actively leaking inside the trailer and breaking containment; the terminal has moved the trailer to the yard. A contractor dispatched and observed an estimated 50-gallon release onto the entire wooden trailer floor and various areas onto the concrete beneath the trailer. The contractor applied oil dry to the release and applied a spill diaper to the leaking metal tote. One 55-gallon DF containing the impacted absorbents was generated. The Shipper will be sending a replacement metal tote to perform a tote transfer. XPO will manage all waste created from the response. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were involved in this incident.

item.title: Report E-2025050036
item.description:
Report E-2025050036

Identified by scraper @ 2025-06-02T15:18:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-04-07
  • City: AUBURN
  • State: WA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: NORTH AMERICAN COMPOSITES COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 161702
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: A warehouse associate loaded a trailer at the NAC Kent (WA) facility with a specific load configuration. The trailer contained thirty-three drums of Interplastic COR61-AA-458K DCPD Laminating Resin, two drums of INEOS Aropol K 1813-14 Resin, and one drum of Interplastic B-1565L-LHM Gel Coat. The drums were loaded first and positioned at the front of the trailer. Additionally, there were seventeen pallets of Ilium Composites fiberglass, which were double-stacked and loaded last. The seventeen pallets of fiberglass were smaller than the pallets used for the metal drums. While transporting a fiberglass pallet with a forklift, the warehouse associate accidentally moved the pallet too far forward in the trailer. This misplacement caused two 55-gallon drums to become punctured, resulting in the contents of both drums spilling onto the wooden floor of the trailer. Meanwhile, a local fire chief, traveling behind our tractor and trailer, noticed the resin leaking. He flagged down the truck driver and advised him to pull over. The truck driver then notified his supervisor, who subsequently informed me (Jerry Davis, VP Operational and Regulatory Affairs at NAC). In response, I contacted Clean Harbors Environmental Services, Inc. for assistance. Clean Harbors arrived at the scene approximately 90 minutes after the spill and initiated an initial cleanup. They removed the pallets from the trailer and identified two leaking drums. After cleaning the trailer on-site, Clean Harbors loaded it, and the NAC truck driver transported the trailer to Kent. Clean Harbors also applied a tarp over the soil area contaminated with polyester resin. Below is a list of the waste debris generated during the initial cleanup. 1. (15) 55-gallon drums of contaminated soil 2. (5) 250-gallon totes of wash water 3. (2) 65-gallon overpack metal drums of debris On April 14, a technician from Clean Harbors visited the site and collected six samples from the contaminated area, which were sent to a laboratory for analysis. The results of these tests are attached. Clean Harbors returned on April 16 to remove approximately 20 cubic yards of contaminated soil. After excavation, they collected another set of six samples and sent those to the laboratory for additional analysis. The second laboratory report indicated that sample number four contained high levels of styrene, a major component of polyester resin. This report was shared with Michael Warfel at the Washington Department of Ecology. He advised NAC to hire a geoengineering firm experienced with state cleanup requirements to prepare a report on any necessary further cleanup actions. NAC notified the Department of Ecology on April 7, 2025. The report number is 738088. NAC also notified the Department of Transportation on April 8, 2025. The report number is 25-1276.

item.title: Report E-2025050033

  • City: CARLISLE

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 23:54 EDT on 4/3, XPO-BCA contacted ERTS to report a spill of about 2 cups of "Lithium Hydroxide Monohydrate" from a 50lb paper bag onto the trailer floor. The bag was punctured by a forklift at BCA. ERTS confirmed the product to be a regulated corrosive and will dispatch a contractor to assist. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1.5 cups of UN3110 Perkadox BCFF product released from (2) 55-pound boxes to the trailer floor due to improper loading. The contractors generated (2) 55-poly drums with the (2) boxes of product. The PPE and spill pads were submerged in water. The waste was staged onsite for terminal to manage.

item.description:

  • City: MOUNT VERNON

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 8500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: EnviroServe - LTL was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted the trailer floor and estimated that fifteen (15) gallons of material was released due to a puncture. EnviroServe – LTL personnel mitigated the spill and containerize material inside of the trailer. Granular absorbents were applied to the affected trailer floor areas. The air pump EnviroServe - LTL brought was having problems so they had to retrieve a new one. The contractor completed the transload onsite after getting the proper equipment. Both the new tote and the empty tote were loaded back onto the trailer. The trailer and cargo were transported back to the ESTES terminal in Effingham, IL where ESTES personnel said they would handle the rest of the cleanup at their terminal. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • City: WEST BRIDGEWATER

  • Description: William Shea, Operations Supervisor, called safety to report a spill in trailer 401238 of UN1133, ADHESIVES, 3, PG II. William stated that while unloading the trailer, a 5-gallon pail was found with the lid peeled back, which he suspects was done by a forklift while being loaded at a different facil ity. William stated that approximately 16 ounces of the adhesive spilled on the trailer floor and on the skid could be a different substance than what is in the pale with the damaged top. He mentioned that they pulled the skid out of the trailer and placed it on cardboard on the dock floor to get a better look at the damaged pail. William believes the spill occurred due to an accident at another facility and spilled during transit.~~William stated that he would shut down the trailer and wait for the cleaning crew to assist in cleaning the skid, the trailer, and removing the pail in a recovery drum. Safety advised William of the ABF Safety Disposal's email.~

item.title: Report E-2025040635
item.description:
Report E-2025040635

Identified by scraper @ 2025-06-01T01:13:35+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-04-26
  • City: JAMESTOWN
  • State: ND
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CREATIVE ENERGY INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 81050
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The truck moved over to the shoulder of the road to let a larger wideload truck pass. The shoulder of the road gave way and the truck slid down the embankment and rolled over. The truck contained 2000 gallons of diesel fuel. A small amount of fuel was leaking out of the vent valves on top of the truck tank. When speaking to the responding officer and fire department, they said very little fuel had spilled. The fire department put floor dry down to soak up fuel that had reached the ground. They also placed spill buckets down to catch any product that was stilling coming out of the vent. The floor dry and top soil have been removed and placed in a container. The truck was placed upright and remaining diesel fuel in the truck tank was transfered into another fuel truck. Diesel fuel release was estimated at 35 minutes from time of incident to containment.

  • Description: On April 25, 2025, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN2735 was punctured and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior and loading dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from GrayMar Environmental Services (GES) to remediate the site. The crew transferred the product to a new tote, and utilized absorbents, hand tools, and neutralizing agent to remediate the site. All impacted material was containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum.

item.title: Report E-2025040652
item.description:
Report E-2025040652

Identified by scraper @ 2025-06-01T01:13:35+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-04-23
  • City: TROY
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 135500
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On February 12, 2025, at 0846 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar Ranger personnel in Troy, MO regarding a vehicle accident that impacted several cargo products. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors found (1) 330-gallon tote of Chlorite solution (UN1908, 8, III), (47) 15-gallon drums of Sodium bisulfate (UN2837, 8, III), and 456 gallons of Citric acid and Copper sulfate pentahydrate (UN1760, 8, III) to be damaged but not leaking. The release was reportedly due to a trailer fire, impacting asphalt and soil. No drains or waterways were impacted by the release. The release was cleaned up with absorbents and the proper PPE. All impacted soil was excavated and backfilled. All waste generated from addressing this release was containerized in (19) roll-offs, (1) 330-gallon tote, and (1) 55-gallon DM which were taken offsite by the contractor for proper disposal. On April 23, 2025, approximately 430 gallons of recovered Sodium bisulfate was transferred into 2 totes. There was 705 gallons of Sodium bisulfate on the BOL - so up to 275 gallons of pH Safe was released or solidified and that is what is included on this report. Again, the confirmed spilled amount of this material was not discovered until April 23, 2025, which is why it is now be reported.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2025-06-01T01:13:35+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-04-21
  • City: CHICAGO
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 16000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: An FRA inspector observed the smell of Ethanol from # UTLX 209125 from the manway cover while performing a regulatory compliance check at the CN Glenn Yard in Chicago, IL. The inspector notified the CN Dangerous Goods Officer who responded to the incident location. The CN Dangerous Goods Officer's inspection of tank car revealed vapor leaking from the gasket sealing surface between the manway nozzle and the manway cover plate indicating a possible gasket failure. This was confirmed by using a 4 gas meter. The manway cover was opened for inspection of the gasket. The gasket appeared to be dry rotted and was replaced. The manway cover swing bolts were then tightened in a star pattern with a 24" pipe wrench.

item.title: Report E-2025040634
item.description:
Report E-2025040634

Identified by scraper @ 2025-06-01T01:13:35+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-04-04
  • City: LOVELAND
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: WORLD FUEL SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 35600
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On 4/4/2025 at 11:15 EST, a World Fuel Services, Inc. (WFS) Cincinnati Tank Wagon driver was making a delivery to a 3,000-gallon aboveground storage tank (AST) located at Loveland Schools Bus Lot in Loveland, OH. During the delivery, the product started overfilling from the AST vent resulting in an uncontrol release of diesel fuel to the environment at 11:25 EST. The employee, after noticing the spill, ran to shut the pump off and then grabbed spill pads to mitigate the spill. The employee attempted to clean-up spill and contacted WFS Operations. WFS Operations contacted WFS HSE personnel to assist with the incident, spill clean-up, and investigation. The employee did not follow procedures and was not at the point of flow during delivery. The employee was distracted by being on their phone away from the delivery point. Truck camera footage showed two minutes, and thirty-five seconds went by until the employee noticed the release. The employee did not confirm ullage by sticking the tank. The release occurred because of human error. The weather on site that day was on and off again precipitation. This contributed to the spill discharging into the detention pond on site. The calculated release is 165 gallons of No. 2 diesel fuel based on reviewing the truck camera footage. The spill impacted the parking lot, storm drain, and a 6,000 square foot detention basin/pond. The NRC was notified of the release on 4/4/25 at 18:00 EST. The Ohio EPA was notified of the release on 4/4/2025 at 18:15 EST. The spill was reported to Hamilton County EMA on 4/4/2025 at 18:30 EST. WFS and Ohio EPA met on-site on 4/8/2025 to determine clean-up plan for the detection pond. Ohio EPA approved WFS/HEPACO to treat the basin with in-situ bioremediation and monitoring the site by taking soil samples for VOCs readings until site is clean and no further action is required. Impacted vegetation (leaves/branches) on the ground were removed. Oil booms were placed at the storm drain’s discharge point and at the outfall of the detention pond. Oil booms are being inspected after precipitation events and replaced as needed. HEPACO/WFS will continue to monitor the in-situ bioremediation and inform the Ohio EPA of its progress.

item.title: Report E-2025040630
item.description:
Report E-2025040630

Identified by scraper @ 2025-05-28T03:42:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-04-09
  • City: MONTGOMERY
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 20:40 PM ET, Alyssa Estes with NMO contacted the call center to report a spill that occurred on the dock in Montgomery, AL. The spill consists of approximately half a gallon of Sure Klean 600, which released from 1-1-gallon plastic jug due to a forklift puncture during dock operations. The spill has impacted the dock floor only. The call center will dispatch a contractor to assist with cleanup as this is a corrosive release. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately (1) 5-gallon jug of UN3264 Sure Klean 600 product released to dock floor due to forklift puncture. The contractors used absorbents to dry up the spill and sprayed with soda ash solution to neutralize it. The impacted pallet was wrapped and was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately one (1) gallon of material released from two (2) 1-gallon metal pails in a paper box due to improperly loaded freight that resulted in the pails leaking. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel gathered the pails and containerized it into one (1) 5-gallon metal drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.
